Die Winkel bleiben erhalten, aber Längen und Flächeninhalte bleiben
aber im Allgemeinen \emph{nicht} erhalten.


\section[Komplexe Integration]{Kurvenintegrale, Komplexe Integration}

Betrachte wieder Kurve $\gamma:I=\left[a,b\right]\to\Omega\subseteq\mathbb{C}$
($\Omega$ offen) sei stetig und stückweise differenzierbar.

TODO: Abb4

Identifiziere zunächst $\mathbb{C}$ mit $\mathbb{R}^{2}$.

Dann kann man die \emph{Bogenlänge} $L\left(\gamma\right)$ folgendermaßen
einführen:
\begin{align*}
L\left(\gamma\right) & =\int_{a}^{b}\left|\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right|\dd\tau
\end{align*}
(Nehme hier zur Einfachheit an, dass $\gamma$ differenzierbar ist,
sonst stückweise integrieren und Integrale addieren.)

$L\left(\gamma\right)$ soll unabhängig von der Parametrisierung sein.
Rechne dies nach:
\begin{align*}
\tilde{\gamma}\left(t\right) & =\left(\gamma\circ\tau\right)\left(t\right) & \tau:\left[\alpha,\beta\right] & \to\left[a,b\right]
\end{align*}
$\tau$ sei streng monoton steigend und $\tau'\left(t\right)\not=0$
für alle $t\in\left[\alpha,\beta\right]$.
\begin{align*}
\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\left|\tilde{\gamma}'\left(t\right)\right|\dd t & \stackrel{\text{Kettenregel}}{=}\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\bigg|\gamma'\left(t\right)\cdot\underbrace{\frac{\dd\tau}{\dd t}}_{>0}\bigg|\dd t=\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\left|\gamma'\left(t\right)\right|\frac{\dd\tau}{\dd t}\dd t=\\
 & \sr{=}{\text{Substitution}}{t=t\left(\tau\right),\dd t=\frac{\dd t}{\dd\tau}\dd t}\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\left|\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right|\dd\tau=L\left(\gamma\right)
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\frac{\dd\tau}{\dd t}\dd t & =\int_{a}^{b}\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau
\end{align*}
Sei nun außerdem $f:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ stetig (wichtigstes Beispiel:
$f$ holomorph).

Wir wollen \quotedblbase{}$f$ längs $\gamma$ integrieren\textquotedblleft{}:
\begin{align*}
\gamma:\left[a,b\right] & \to\mathbb{C}
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\int_{a}^{b}f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\left|\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right|\dd\tau
\end{align*}
Dies wäre eine Möglichkeit, denn dies ist unabhängig von der Parametrisierung.

In der komplexen Analysis ist das Integral
\begin{align*}
\int_{a}^{b}f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau
\end{align*}
interessanter, weil keine komplexe Konjugation eingeht.


\subsection{Definition \textmd{(komplexes Integral)}}

Sei $\gamma:\left[a,b\right]\to\Omega\subseteq\mathbb{C}$ stetig
und stückweise differenzierbar und $f:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ stetig.

Dann heißt
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z & :=\int_{a}^{b}f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau
\end{align*}
das \emph{komplexe Integral} oder \emph{Konturintegral} von $f$ über
$\gamma$.


\subsubsection*{Beachte}

Wir integrieren über eine \emph{reelle Variable} $t\in\left[a,b\right]$,
aber der Integrand ist komplexwertig.

Man kann das auf reellwertige Integrale zurückführen.
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z & :=\int_{a}^{b}\text{Re}\left(f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right)\dd\tau+\ii\int_{a}^{b}\text{Im}\left(f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right)\dd\tau
\end{align*}
Riemann- beziehungsweise Lebesgue-Integral im Reellen.

Insbesondere sieht man:
\begin{align*}
\text{Re}\left(\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z\right) & =\int_{a}^{b}\text{Re}\big(f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\big)\dd\tau\\
 & \not=\int_{\gamma}\text{Re}\left(f\left(z\right)\right)\dd z=\int_{a}^{b}\text{Re}\big(f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\big)\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau
\end{align*}



\subsection{Satz}

${\displaystyle \int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z}$ ist unabhängig
von der Parametrisierung.


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

Sei $t:\left[\alpha,\beta\right]\to\left[a,b\right]$ streng monoton
steigend, stetig, stückweise differenzierbar.

Dann folgt mit $\tilde{\gamma}\left(\tau\right)=\left(\gamma\circ t\right)\left(\tau\right)$:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\left(f\circ\gamma\circ t\right)\left(\tau\right)\cdot\left(\gamma\circ t\right)'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau & =\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\left(f\circ\gamma\right)\left(t\left(\tau\right)\right)\cdot\gamma'\left(t\left(\tau\right)\right)\frac{\dd t}{\dd\tau}\dd\tau=\\
 & \stackrel{\text{Transformationsformel}}{=}\int_{\alpha}^{\beta}\left(f\circ\gamma\right)\left(t\right)\cdot\gamma'\left(t\right)\dd t
\end{align*}
\qqed


\subsection{Beispiel}

\begin{iiilist}

\iii ${\displaystyle f\left(z\right)=\frac{1}{z^{2}}}$, $\gamma:\left[1,2\right]\to\mathbb{C}:t\mapsto t$
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int_{1}^{2}f\left(\gamma\left(t\right)\right)\gamma'\left(t\right)\dd t=\int_{1}^{2}\frac{1}{t^{2}}\cdot1\dd t=\frac{-1}{t}\bigg|_{1}^{2}=\frac{-1}{2}+1=\frac{1}{2}
\end{align*}


%DATE Fr 23.12.2011

\iii $f\left(z\right)=z^{n},\: n\ge0$\\
Wähle eine Parametrisierung zum Beispiel

\begin{align*}
\gamma_{1}:\left[0,1\right] & \to\mathbb{C}\\
\gamma_{1}\left(\tau\right) & =\tau\left(1+\ii\right)\\
\gamma_{1}'\left(\tau\right) & =\left(1+\ii\right)
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma_{1}}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int_{0}^{1}f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\cdot\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau=\int_{0}^{1}\left(\left(1+\ii\right)\cdot\tau\right)^{n}\cdot\left(1+\ii\right)\dd\tau=\\
 & =\left(1+\ii\right)^{n+1}\cdot\int_{0}^{1}\tau^{n}\dd\tau=\frac{1}{n+1}\cdot\left(1+\ii\right)^{n+1}
\end{align*}
$\gamma_{2}$: Parametrisiere so:
\begin{align*}
\gamma_{2}:\left[0,2\right] & \to\mathbb{C}\\
\gamma\left(\tau\right) & =\begin{cases}
\tau & 0\le\tau\le1\\
\left(1+\left(\tau-1\right)\ii\right) & 1\le\tau\le2
\end{cases}\\
\gamma'\left(\tau\right) & =\begin{cases}
1 & 0<\tau<1\\
\ii & 1<\tau<2
\end{cases}
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma_{2}}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int_{0}^{1}\tau^{n}\cdot1\dd\tau+\int_{1}^{2}\left(1+\left(\tau-1\right)\cdot\ii\right)^{n}\cdot\ii\dd\tau=\frac{1}{n+1}+\ii\cdot\frac{1}{\left(n+1\right)\ii}\left(1+\left(\tau-1\right)\ii\right)^{n+1}\bigg|_{1}^{2}=\\
 & =\frac{1}{n+1}+\frac{1}{n+1}\left(\left(1+\ii\right)^{n+1}-1\right)=\frac{1}{n+1}\cdot\left(1+\ii\right)^{n+1}
\end{align*}


\end{iiilist}

Der Wert des Integrals ist also für beide Integrationswege gleich.


\subsection{Definition}

Sei $\gamma:\left[0,1\right]\to\mathbb{C}$.

Setze
\begin{align*}
-\gamma & :=\tilde{\gamma}:\left[0,1\right]\to\mathbb{C},\:\tilde{\gamma}\left(\tau\right)=\gamma\left(1-\tau\right)
\end{align*}
also \quotedblbase{}durchlaufe die Kurve rückwärts\textquotedblleft{}.

Sei $\gamma_{1}:\left[a,b\right]\to\mathbb{C}$ und $\gamma_{2}:\left[b,c\right]\to\mathbb{C}$
mit $\gamma_{1}\left(b\right)=\gamma_{2}\left(b\right)$.\\
Setze dann $\gamma_{1}+\gamma_{2}:\left[a,c\right]\to\mathbb{C}$
definiert durch: 
\begin{align*}
\left(\gamma_{1}+\gamma_{2}\right)\left(\tau\right) & =\begin{cases}
\gamma_{1}\left(\tau\right) & \tau\in\left[a,b\right]\\
\gamma_{2}\left(\tau\right) & \tau\in\left[b,c\right]
\end{cases}
\end{align*}



\subsection{Lemma}

\begin{align*}
\int_{-\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =-\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma_{1}+\ldots+\gamma_{n}}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int_{\gamma_{1}}f\left(z\right)\dd z+\ldots+\int_{\gamma_{n}}f\left(z\right)\dd z
\end{align*}



\subsubsection*{Beweis}

TODO: Fehlt???


\subsection{Definition}

Setze:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd\overline{z} & =\overline{\int_{\gamma}\overline{f\left(z\right)}\dd z}\\
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd x & =\frac{1}{2}\left(\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z+\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd\overline{z}\right)\\
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd y & =\frac{1}{2\ii}\left(\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z-\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd\overline{z}\right)
\end{align*}
Dann gilt:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd x+\ii\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd y
\end{align*}
Also: \quotedblbase{}$\dd z=\dd x+\ii\dd y$\textquotedblleft{}

Etwas ausführlicher:
\begin{align*}
x+\ii y & =z=\gamma\left(\tau\right)\\
x\left(\tau\right) & :=\text{Re}\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right) & \Rightarrow\quad\text{Re}\left(\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right) & =x'\left(\tau\right)\\
y\left(\tau\right) & :=\text{Im}\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right) & \Rightarrow\quad\text{Im}\left(\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right) & =y'\left(\tau\right)\\
\dd x & =x'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau\\
\dd y & =y'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int_{a}^{b}f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau\\
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd\overline{z} & =\overline{\int_{\gamma}\overline{f\left(z\right)}\dd z}=\int_{a}^{b}\overline{f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)}\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\dd\tau=\int_{a}^{b}f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\overline{\gamma'\left(\tau\right)}\dd\tau\\
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd x & =\int_{a}^{b}f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\cdot\underbrace{\text{Re}\left(\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right)}_{=x'\left(\tau\right)}\dd\tau\\
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd y & =\int_{a}^{b}f\left(\gamma\left(\tau\right)\right)\cdot\underbrace{\text{Im}\left(\gamma'\left(\tau\right)\right)}_{=y'\left(\tau\right)}\dd\tau\\
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd y & =\int_{\gamma}p\dd x+\int_{y}q\dd y
\end{align*}
Später: Setze $p=f$ und $q=\ii f$.


\section[Weg(un)abhängigkeit]{Abhängigkeit vom Integrationsgebiet}

Sei $\Omega\subseteq\mathbb{C}$ offen, $z_{0},z\in\Omega$, $p,q:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$
stetig und wegzusammenhängend.


\subsubsection*{Frage}

Wann gilt folgende Gleichheit?
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma_{1}}\left(p\dd x+q\dd y\right) & =\int_{\gamma_{2}}\left(p\dd x+q\dd y\right)
\end{align*}
Seien $\gamma_{1},\gamma_{2}$ zwei differenzierbare Kurven, die $z_{0}$
mit $z$ verbinden.

TODO: Abb2


\subsubsection*{Allgemeine Frage}

Wann ist das Integral unabhängig vom Weg?


\subsection{Theorem\label{sub:Theo-wegunabh=0000E4ngig}}

Das Linienintegral
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}\left(p\dd x+q\dd y\right)
\end{align*}
ist genau dann wegunabhängig, wenn es eine Funktion $U:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$
gibt, so dass:
\begin{align}
p & =\frac{\partial U}{\partial x} & q & =\frac{\partial U}{\partial y}\label{eq:pUxqUy}
\end{align}
(Frobenius, Poincaré, $\ldots$)


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

\quotedblbase{}$\Leftarrow$\textquotedblleft{}: Nehme an, dass \eqref{eq:pUxqUy}
gilt, womit folgt:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}\left(p\dd x+q\dd y\right) & =\int_{a}^{b}\left(\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}x'\left(\tau\right)\dd x+\frac{\partial U}{\partial y}y'\left(\tau\right)\dd y\right)=\int_{a}^{b}\frac{\dd}{\dd\tau}\left(U\left(x\left(\tau\right),y\left(\tau\right)\right)\right)=\\
 & =U\left(x\left(b\right),y\left(b\right)\right)-U\left(x\left(a\right),y\left(a\right)\right)=U\left(z\right)-U\left(z_{0}\right)
\end{align*}
Also hängt das Integral tatsächlich nur von Anfangs- und Endpunkt
ab.

\quotedblbase{}$\Rightarrow$\textquotedblleft{}: Nehmen an, dass
das Integral wegunabhängig ist.

$z_{0}=\left(x_{0},y_{0}\right)$ sei fest, während $z=\left(x,y\right)$
variabel.

Wähle als Kurve speziell ein Polygonzug, der parallel zur $x$- oder
$y$-Achse verläuft.

TODO: Abb3

$\gamma$ kann durch einen solchen Polygonzug approximiert werden.

Verwende hierbei, dass $\Omega$ offen und bogenzusammenhängend ist.

Definiere:
\begin{align*}
U\left(x,y\right) & :=\int_{\gamma}\left(p\dd x+q\dd y\right)
\end{align*}
Dies ist wohldefiniert, weil das Integral nach Voraussetzung wegunabhängig
ist.

Berechne ${\displaystyle \frac{\partial U}{\partial x}}$:

Wähle den Polygonzug so, dass er in einer Umgebung von $\left(x,y\right)$
horizontal verläuft.

Dann gilt:
\begin{align*}
U\left(x,y\right) & =\int^{x}p\left(\tilde{x},y\right)\dd\tilde{x}+\text{Konstante}\\
\frac{\partial U}{\partial x} & =p\left(x,y\right)
\end{align*}
Berechne ${\displaystyle \frac{\partial U}{\partial x}}$:

Wähle den Polygonzug so, dass er in einer Umgebung von $\left(x,y\right)$
vertikal verläuft.

Dann gilt:
\begin{align*}
U\left(x,y\right) & =\int^{y}q\left(x,\tilde{y}\right)\dd\tilde{y}+\text{Konstante}\\
\frac{\partial U}{\partial y} & =q\left(x,y\right)
\end{align*}


Also sind die Differentialgleichungen \eqref{eq:pUxqUy} erfüllt.\\
\qqed

Schreibe auch:
\begin{align*}
\int p\dd x+q\dd y & =U\\
p\dd x+q\dd y & =\frac{\partial U}{\partial x}\dd x+\frac{\partial U}{\partial y}\dd y\left(=:\dd U\right)
\end{align*}
Und man nennt $\dd U$ das \emph{totale Differential}.

Das totale Differential ist \emph{exakt}, das heißt es kann in obiger
Form geschrieben werden.

Zurück zum Konturintegral:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int\bigg(\underbrace{f}_{=p}\dd x+\underbrace{\ii f}_{=q}\dd y\bigg)
\end{align*}
Nach Theorem \ref{sub:Theo-wegunabh=0000E4ngig} ist das Konturintegral
genau dann wegunabhängig, wenn ein $F\left(z\right)$ in $\Omega$
existiert, so dass gilt:
\begin{align*}
\frac{\partial F}{\partial x} & =f\left(z\right) & \frac{\partial F}{\partial y} & =\ii f\left(z\right)
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\Rightarrow\quad\frac{\partial F}{\partial x} & =-\ii\frac{\partial F}{\partial y}
\end{align*}
Also erfüllt $F$ die Cauchy-Riemannschen Differentialgleichungen
und $f\left(z\right)=F'\left(z\right)$.


\subsection{Korollar}

$\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z$ ist genau dann wegunabhängig,
wenn es eine holomorphe Funktion $F:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ gibt mit
$f\left(z\right)=F'\left(z\right)$.


\subsubsection*{Beweis}

TODO: ???


\subsection{Satz\label{sub:Satz-PolyOint0}}

Für jedes Polynom $P\left(z\right)$ und jede geschlossene Kurve gilt:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\gamma}P\left(z\right)\dd z & =0
\end{align*}



\subsubsection*{Beweis}

\begin{align*}
P\left(z\right) & =a_{n}z^{n}+a_{n-1}z^{n-1}+\ldots+a_{0}\\
Q\left(z\right) & =\frac{a_{n}}{n+1}z^{n+1}+\frac{a_{n-1}}{n}z^{n}+\ldots+a_{0}z
\end{align*}
$Q\left(z\right)$ ist eine holomorphe Stammfunktion, also $Q'\left(z\right)=P\left(z\right)$.\\
\qqed


\section{Das Cauchysche Theorem}

Betrachte das Rechteck $R:a\le x\le b,\, c\le y\le d$. $R\subseteq\Omega\subseteq\mathbb{C}$

TODO: Abb4


\subsubsection*{Fragen}

Falls $f:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ holomorph ist,
\begin{enumerate}
\item gibt es eine holomorphe Stammfunktion, also $F:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$
mit $F'\left(z\right)=f\left(z\right)$?
\item ist $\int_{\gamma}f\left(z\right)\dd z$ wegunabhängig?
\end{enumerate}
Beginne mit einfachen Integrationswegen und zwar dem Integral längs
des Randes von $R$.


\subsection{Theorem}


\subsubsection*{Ist $f:\Omega\to\mathbb{C}$ holomorph, so gilt:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\partial R}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =0
\end{align*}
Beweis \textmd{(nach Goursat)}}

Zerlege $R$ in vier kongruente Rechtecke $R^{\left(1\right)},\ldots,R^{\left(4\right)}$.

TODO: Abb5

\begin{align*}
\int_{\partial R}f\left(z\right)\dd z & =\int_{\partial R^{\left(1\right)}}f\left(z\right)\dd z+\ldots+\int_{\partial R^{\left(4\right)}}f\left(z\right)\dd z
\end{align*}
Dies gilt, da sich die Integrale längs der \quotedblbase{}inneren
Kanten\textquotedblleft{} wegheben.

Für eines der Rechtecke $R^{\left(k\right)}$ gilt und nenne es $R_{1}$:
\begin{align*}
\left|\int_{\partial R_{1}}f\left(z\right)\dd z\right| & \ge\frac{1}{4}\left|\int_{\partial R}f\left(z\right)\right|
\end{align*}
Wähle induktiv Rechtecke $R\supseteq R_{1}\supseteq R_{2}\supseteq\ldots$,
so dass gilt:
\begin{align*}
\left|\eta\left(R_{n}\right)\right| & \ge\frac{1}{4^{n}}\left|\eta\left(R\right)\right|
\end{align*}
Zudem sind die Kantenlängen von $R_{n}$ schon $2^{-n}$ mal die Kantenlängen
von $R$.

Seien $Z_{n}$ die Mittelpunkte dieser Rechtecke.

Die Folge $\left(z_{n}\right)$ konvergiert gegen $z^{*}\in R$.

TODO: Abb6

Da $f$ in $z^{*}$ holomorph ist, gibt es zu jedem $\varepsilon>0$
ein $\delta>0$, so dass gilt für alle $z\in B_{\delta}\left(z^{*}\right)\setminus\left\{ z^{*}\right\} $:
\begin{align*}
\left|\frac{f\left(z\right)-f\left(z^{*}\right)}{z-z^{*}}-f'\left(z^{*}\right)\right| & <\varepsilon
\end{align*}
Wähle nun $n$ so groß, dass $R_{n}\subseteq B_{\delta}\left(z^{*}\right)$
ist.

Dann gilt:
\begin{align*}
\int_{\partial R_{n}}\left[f\left(z^{*}\right)+f'\left(z^{*}\right)\left(z-z^{*}\right)\right] & \stackrel{\ref{sub:Satz-PolyOint0}}{=}0
\end{align*}
Beachte dabei, das wir ein Polynom integrieren.
\begin{align*}
\left|\eta\left(R_{n}\right)\right| & =\left|\int_{\partial R_{n}}f\left(z\right)\dd z\right|=\Bigg|\int_{\partial R_{n}}\bigg(\underbrace{f\left(z\right)-f\left(z^{*}\right)-f'\left(z^{*}\right)\left(z-z^{*}\right)}_{\left|\ldots\right|\le\varepsilon\left|z-z^{*}\right|}\bigg)\dd z\Bigg|\le\varepsilon\Bigg|\int_{\partial R_{n}}\underbrace{\left|z-z^{*}\right|}_{\le2^{-n}\cdot\max\left\{ b-a,d-c\right\} }\dd z\Bigg|\le\\
 & \le\varepsilon\cdot4^{-n}\cdot\underbrace{d}_{\text{Durchmesser von }R}\cdot\underbrace{L}_{\text{Umfang von }R}
\end{align*}
Damit folgt:
\begin{align*}
\eta\left(R\right) & \le\varepsilon\cdot d\cdot L
\end{align*}
Da $\varepsilon$ beliebig ist, folgt $\eta\left(R\right)=0$.\\
\qqed

\section*{\noun{0. Preamble}}

\noindent The purpose of this License is to make a manual, textbook,
or other functional and useful document \textquotedblleft{}free\textquotedblright{}
in the sense of freedom: to assure everyone the effective freedom
to copy and redistribute it, with or without modifying it, either
commercially or noncommercially. Secondarily, this License preserves
for the author and publisher a way to get credit for their work, while
not being considered responsible for modifications made by others.

\noindent This License is a kind of \textquotedblleft{}copyleft\textquotedblright{},
which means that derivative works of the document must themselves
be free in the same sense. It complements the GNU General Public License,
which is a copyleft license designed for free software.

\noindent We have designed this License in order to use it for manuals
for free software, because free software needs free documentation:
a free program should come with manuals providing the same freedoms
that the software does. But this License is not limited to software
manuals; it can be used for any textual work, regardless of subject
matter or whether it is published as a printed book. We recommend
this License principally for works whose purpose is instruction or
reference.


\section*{\noun{1. Applicability and definitions}}

This License applies to any manual or other work, in any medium, that
contains a notice placed by the copyright holder saying it can be
distributed under the terms of this License. Such a notice grants
a world-wide, royalty-free license, unlimited in duration, to use
that work under the conditions stated herein. The \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Document}\textquotedblright{},
below, refers to any such manual or work. Any member of the public
is a licensee, and is addressed as \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{you}\textquotedblright{}.
You accept the license if you copy, modify or distribute the work
in a way requiring permission under copyright law.

A \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Modified Version}\textquotedblright{}
of the Document means any work containing the Document or a portion
of it, either copied verbatim, or with modifications and/or translated
into another language.

A \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Secondary Section}\textquotedblright{}
is a named appendix or a front-matter section of the Document that
deals exclusively with the relationship of the publishers or authors
of the Document to the Document's overall subject (or to related matters)
and contains nothing that could fall directly within that overall
subject. (Thus, if the Document is in part a textbook of mathematics,
a Secondary Section may not explain any mathematics.) The relationship
could be a matter of historical connection with the subject or with
related matters, or of legal, commercial, philosophical, ethical or
political position regarding them.

The \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Invariant Sections}\textquotedblright{}
are certain Secondary Sections whose titles are designated, as being
those of Invariant Sections, in the notice that says that the Document
is released under this License. If a section does not fit the above
definition of Secondary then it is not allowed to be designated as
Invariant. The Document may contain zero Invariant Sections. If the
Document does not identify any Invariant Sections then there are none.

The \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Cover Texts}\textquotedblright{} are
certain short passages of text that are listed, as Front-Cover Texts
or Back-Cover Texts, in the notice that says that the Document is
released under this License. A Front-Cover Text may be at most 5 words,
and a Back-Cover Text may be at most 25 words.

A \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Transparent}\textquotedblright{} copy
of the Document means a machine-readable copy, represented in a format
whose specification is available to the general public, that is suitable
for revising the document straightforwardly with generic text editors
or (for images composed of pixels) generic paint programs or (for
drawings) some widely available drawing editor, and that is suitable
for input to text formatters or for automatic translation to a variety
of formats suitable for input to text formatters. A copy made in an
otherwise Transparent file format whose markup, or absence of markup,
has been arranged to thwart or discourage subsequent modification
by readers is not Transparent. An image format is not Transparent
if used for any substantial amount of text. A copy that is not \textquotedblleft{}Transparent\textquotedblright{}
is called \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Opaque}\textquotedblright{}.

Examples of suitable formats for Transparent copies include plain
ASCII without markup, Texinfo input format, \LaTeX{} input format,
SGML or XML using a publicly available DTD, and standard-conforming
simple HTML, PostScript or PDF designed for human modification. Examples
of transparent image formats include PNG, XCF and JPG. Opaque formats
include proprietary formats that can be read and edited only by proprietary
word processors, SGML or XML for which the DTD and/or processing tools
are not generally available, and the machine-generated HTML, PostScript
or PDF produced by some word processors for output purposes only.

The \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Title Page}\textquotedblright{} means,
for a printed book, the title page itself, plus such following pages
as are needed to hold, legibly, the material this License requires
to appear in the title page. For works in formats which do not have
any title page as such, \textquotedblleft{}Title Page\textquotedblright{}
means the text near the most prominent appearance of the work's title,
preceding the beginning of the body of the text.

The \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{publisher}\textquotedblright{} means
any person or entity that distributes copies of the Document to the
public.

A section \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Entitled XYZ}\textquotedblright{}
means a named subunit of the Document whose title either is precisely
XYZ or contains XYZ in parentheses following text that translates
XYZ in another language. (Here XYZ stands for a specific section name
mentioned below, such as \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Acknowledgements}\textquotedblright{},
\textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Dedications}\textquotedblright{}, \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Endorsements}\textquotedblright{},
or \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{History}\textquotedblright{}.) To \textquotedblleft{}\textbf{Preserve
the Title}\textquotedblright{} of such a section when you modify the
Document means that it remains a section \textquotedblleft{}Entitled
XYZ\textquotedblright{} according to this definition.

The Document may include Warranty Disclaimers next to the notice which
states that this License applies to the Document. These Warranty Disclaimers
are considered to be included by reference in this License, but only
as regards disclaiming warranties: any other implication that these
Warranty Disclaimers may have is void and has no effect on the meaning
of this License.

You may copy and distribute the Document in any medium, either commercially

\section*{\noun{3. Copying in quantity}}

If you publish printed copies (or copies in media that commonly have
printed covers) of the Document, numbering more than 100, and the
Document's license notice requires Cover Texts, you must enclose the
copies in covers that carry, clearly and legibly, all these Cover
Texts: Front-Cover Texts on the front cover, and Back-Cover Texts
on the back cover. Both covers must also clearly and legibly identify
you as the publisher of these copies. The front cover must present
the full title with all words of the title equally prominent and visible.
You may add other material on the covers in addition. Copying with
changes limited to the covers, as long as they preserve the title
of the Document and satisfy these conditions, can be treated as verbatim
copying in other respects.

If the required texts for either cover are too voluminous to fit legibly,
you should put the first ones listed (as many as fit reasonably) on
the actual cover, and continue the rest onto adjacent pages.

If you publish or distribute Opaque copies of the Document numbering
more than 100, you must either include a machine-readable Transparent
copy along with each Opaque copy, or state in or with each Opaque
copy a computer-network location from which the general network-using
public has access to download using public-standard network protocols
a complete Transparent copy of the Document, free of added material.
If you use the latter option, you must take reasonably prudent steps,
when you begin distribution of Opaque copies in quantity, to ensure
that this Transparent copy will remain thus accessible at the stated
location until at least one year after the last time you distribute
an Opaque copy (directly or through your agents or retailers) of that
edition to the public.

It is requested, but not required, that you contact the authors of
the Document well before redistributing any large number of copies,
to give them a chance to provide you with an updated version of the
Document.

and modification of the Modified Version to whoever possesses a copy
of it. In addition, you must do these things in the Modified Version:
\begin{description}
\item [{A.\hspace*{3.2mm}}] Use in the Title Page (and on the covers,
if any) a title distinct from that of the Document, and from those
of previous versions (which should, if there were any, be listed in

\item [{L.\hspace*{4.1mm}}] Preserve all the Invariant Sections of the

If the Modified Version includes new front-matter sections or appendices
that qualify as Secondary Sections and contain no material copied

If the Document specifies that a particular numbered version of this
License \textquotedbl{}or any later version\textquotedbl{} applies
to it, you have the option of following the terms and conditions either
of that specified version or of any later version that has been published
(not as a draft) by the Free Software Foundation. If the Document
does not specify a version number of this License, you may choose
any version ever published (not as a draft) by the Free Software Foundation.
If the Document specifies that a proxy can decide which future versions
of this License can be used, that proxy's public statement of acceptance
of a version permanently authorizes you to choose that version for
the Document.


\section*{\noun{11. Relicensing}}

\textquotedblleft{}Massive Multiauthor Collaboration Site\textquotedblright{}
(or \textquotedblleft{}MMC Site\textquotedblright{}) means any World
Wide Web server that publishes copyrightable works and also provides
prominent facilities for anybody to edit those works. A public wiki
that anybody can edit is an example of such a server. A \textquotedblleft{}Massive
Multiauthor Collaboration\textquotedblright{} (or \textquotedblleft{}MMC\textquotedblright{})
contained in the site means any set of copyrightable works thus published
on the MMC site.

\textquotedblleft{}CC-BY-SA\textquotedblright{} means the Creative
Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 license published by Creative
Commons Corporation, a not-for-profit corporation with a principal
place of business in San Francisco, California, as well as future
copyleft versions of that license published by that same organization.

\textquotedblleft{}Incorporate\textquotedblright{} means to publish
or republish a Document, in whole or in part, as part of another Document.

An MMC is \textquotedblleft{}eligible for relicensing\textquotedblright{}
if it is licensed under this License, and if all works that were first
published under this License somewhere other than this MMC, and subsequently
incorporated in whole or in part into the MMC, (1) had no cover texts
or invariant sections, and (2) were thus incorporated prior to November
1, 2008.

The operator of an MMC Site may republish an MMC contained in the
site under CC-BY-SA on the same site at any time before August 1,
2009, provided the MMC is eligible for relicensing.


\section*{\noun{Addendum}: How to use this License for your documents}

To use this License in a document you have written, include a copy
of the License in the document and put the following copyright and
license notices just after the title page:
\begin{quote}
Copyright © YEAR YOUR NAME.\\
Permission is granted to copy, distribute and/or modify this document
under the terms of the GNU Free Documentation License, Version 1.3
or any later version published by the Free Software Foundation;

with no Invariant Sections, no Front-Cover Texts, and no Back-Cover
Texts.

A copy of the license is included in the section entitled \textquotedbl{}GNU
Free Documentation License\textquotedbl{}.
\end{quote}
If you have Invariant Sections, Front-Cover Texts and Back-Cover Texts,
replace the \textquotedbl{}with $\ldots$ Texts.\textquotedbl{} line
with this:
\begin{quote}
with the Invariant Sections being LIST THEIR TITLES, with the Front-Cover
Texts being LIST, and with the Back-Cover Texts being LIST.
\end{quote}
If you have Invariant Sections without Cover Texts, or some other
combination of the three, merge those two alternatives to suit the
situation.

If your document contains nontrivial examples of program code, we
recommend releasing these examples in parallel under your choice of
free software license, such as the GNU General Public License, to
permit their use in free software.
